text.text:
### Distortions

Destroying a person's reputation is an ancient practice widely employed throughout history. Various strategies have been used over time, including defamation, lies, and, more recently, fake news. In this section, we will focus on the first of these strategies, which was extensively utilized by the Camargo family against their enemies.

### What is Defamation?

Before analyzing this concept, it is important to understand how it is defined by the Cambridge Dictionary

text: • the action of damaging the reputation of a person or group by saying or writing bad things about them that are not true.

text.text:
### Why Was Being Jewish Considered Defamatory?

Based on our understanding of biological sciences and evolutionary theory, claiming that a person is inferior because they belong to a specific human group has no scientific basis. The genetic differences among human populations are so minimal that the concept of "races" is biologically invalid

However, the biological —and therefore natural— principle of equality is not always recognized among humans. History is rife with examples of discrimination. Beyond the atrocities of human slavery, being Jewish or having Jewish ancestry has been used as a justification to marginalize, demean, and even criminalize individuals, as documented by Antonio José Saraiva in his work

### How Was Defamation Created? (Part I)

During the period of the Inquisition, many Jews in Portugal were forced to convert to Christianity to avoid execution, becoming known as "new Christians". However, the prejudice and hatred previously directed at the Jewish community were soon redirected towards these converts, fueled by the rhetoric of certain Christian leaders

The disqualification of individuals by the Inquisition was carried out systematically and arbitrarily, with no possibility of appeal. To persecute someone, the Inquisition used various methods, including fabricated evidence, infiltration of agents into prisons to provoke inmates, and manipulated legal proceedings

### How Was Defamation Created? (Part II)

In Damião de Góis' chronicle, an incident is described that took place in a church in Lisbon. During a religious celebration, some attendees claimed to have witnessed a miracle involving a crucifix. However, one individual present questioned the supposed "miracle", explaining that it was merely the reflection of a candle on the cross. This person was immediately accused of being a new Christian, then murdered and burned.

This event sparked a wave of violence incited by two clergymen, who led the population into the streets. As a result, approximately 2,000 new Christians, including women and children, were brutally persecuted and killed in a horrific massacre

source.text: Gois, Damião de, Parte I, Cap. Cii, pp. 230 - 232

text.text:
### How Was Defamation Created? (Part III)

Francisco Gomes Henriques, a Christian devotee of Our Lady of Glory and the father of a monseñor who openly opposed the Inquisition and was under the Pope’s protection. Despite these circumstances, Henriques was persecuted, arrested, and subjected to a manipulated trial. Agents of the Inquisition were placed in his prison cell to provoke him into making statements that could be used to incriminate him as a Jew.

Letters written by Henriques to his wife, which were confiscated by the Inquisition, provide additional evidence of his Christian faith

### How Was Defamation Created? (Part IV)

António José da Silva's family, like the example previously discussed, was Christian, with several members serving as priests and friars. However, this family possessed traits that drew the Inquisition's attention: they were wealthy, educated, and included several lawyers. António's parents and brothers were arrested but later released after being forced to confess and accuse others.

When António was imprisoned, his wife and mother were also detained. However, António received markedly different treatment compared to the two women, indicating the Inquisition's particular interest in him. This selective focus reflected the institution's intent to derive greater benefits from his persecution, likely due to his social status and the family's influence

### How Was Defamation Created? (Part V) In Chapter V, António José Saraiva recounts another absurd case fabricated by the Inquisition, this time involving Manuel Fernandes Vila Real. Initially, Vila Real was not targeted by the Inquisition as he was living in France. However, upon his return to Portugal to receive a commendation, he became the subject of persecution, particularly due to his opposition to the Fisco Inquisitorial and the practices of the Holy Office tribunal. Before his arrest, he published a book later translated into Spanish under the title El político Christianissimo Manuel Fernandes Vila Real was accused of being a "slanderer, insulter, and obstructer of the Holy Office". As was common, the tribunal employed extreme methods to coerce him into confessing that he was a Jew. Among these measures, they claimed he practiced regular fasting during his imprisonment, alleging that he ate fewer than five days per week for three consecutive years

### How Was Defamation Created? (Part VI)

The methods employed by the Portuguese Inquisition resulted in a paradoxical statistic. While in Spain, the number of Jews persecuted decreased over time, the Portuguese Inquisition's so-called "Jew factory" maintained a significant number of new Christians even after 80 years of persecution

The issues were not confined to the metropole. In the early stages of colonization, the Inquisition paid little attention to Jews in Brazil. However, as Jews became owners of sugar mills in Brazilian territory, the situation changed significantly

In both Portuguese and Spanish colonies, the "Jew factory" adapted its actions to local circumstances. During the Iberian Union, for example, Spanish Jesuits persecuted and even killed Portuguese Catholics

### Beginning of the Phase

Following the introduction, which explores various false accusations and "conversions" orchestrated by the Inquisition itself, as explained by António José Saraiva, it becomes evident that these are not isolated incidents, as the Inquisition's own statistics demonstrate

On Credibility
Given that the lawsuits were manipulated and that a "factory" for creating new Christians existed, can we truly trust a legal process without thoroughly examining the life of the accused?
desc: The examples analyzed by Antonio José Saraiva, along with the upcoming examples to be examined at this stage, demonstrate that it is impossible to define a person solely by reading an ancient document, whether complete or partial. To truly understand the events surrounding a person, it is essential to study their life and the context in which they lived.

### The Paulista Civil War

During the Paulista Civil War, the Camargo family extensively employed the strategy of redirecting the Inquisition’s attention toward specific families. This effort is documented through various diligences involving relatives of the Holy Office and Bachelor, in addition to analyses of testimonies and probatory documents. These actions are well-recorded in historical archives and supported by formal evidence

### An Incomplete Document (Part II)

From the preserved document fragment, we learn that his maternal grandmother was described as having a "constant fama" of being a New Christian. This raises the need for a deeper investigation to determine whether the family indeed had Jewish origins or if this is yet another case of persecution by the Portuguese Inquisition

### An Incomplete Document (Part III)

Furthermore, it is possible to reconstruct Garcia Roiz Paes' family tree using the Familiar Habilitation for the Holy Office filed by his son, Pedro Dias Paes

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

Our first step is to formulate a question:

Reflection 1: On Ancestors
Although the document mentions only Garcia Roiz Paes' maternal grandmother, we will expand the investigation to gain a better understanding of the Inquisition context.

Does Garcia Roiz Paes have any New Christian ancestors?
Now, we need to define the hypotheses (possible answers) we want to test:
HIPOTHESIS 1: There is at least one New Christian ancestor.
HIPOTHESIS 2: There are no New Christian ancestors.

text.text:
### The Paternal Lineage (Part I)

José Gonçalves Salvador raised a suspicion that García Roiz Paes had Jewish ancestry in his paternal lineage was raised by. He mentions an episode where Fernão Dias Paes had a disagreement with D. Francisco de Sousa, who referred to him as a "Jew dog". However, José Gonçalves Salvador notes that Francisco de Sousa later apologized for the incident

To support this claim, José Gonçalves Salvador emphasizes that the "purity of blood" granted to Fernão Dias Paes' "brothers" did not automatically extend to him. Moreover, as demonstrated in the Leme family study, based on various primary sources, the genealogical tree attributed to Fernão Dias Paes was falsified to fabricate a patrilineal lineage

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 12 - 14

text.text: ### The Paternal Lineage (Parte II) The hypothesis raised about Fernão Dias Paes remained unproven years later, as indicated by José Gonçalves Salvador in another publication: "Fernão Dias Paes Leme, que, si no era de linaje, estuvo casado con una señora de estirpe cristiana nueva"

We will delve into the details of Maria Garcia's alleged status as a New Christian later. For now, we conclude the analysis regarding the "Jew dog" episode by referencing another excerpt from Salvador's work, where he describes the strategy used by the Camargos against their adversaries

text: • "... la fama de cristiano nuevo, levantada en tiempos de los Camargos, quienes, además, lo habían llamado judío. ¿Calumnia de la oposición? Tal vez. Era una forma de venganza común en aquellos días..."

text.text:
### The Paternal Lineage (Part III)

In the following generation, Pedro Dias married Maria Leite. Genetic analyses and contemporary historical documents indicate that Maria Leite had indigenous ancestors, with the exception of her maternal grandfather, João do Prado, who was born in Olivença, Portugal, and a maternal great-grandparent, Pedro Vicente, about whom little is known

text: Since no Jewish ancestry was identified in the paternal lineage using the available data, we now turn our attention to the maternal lineage, specifically the marriage between Fernão Dias Paes and Maria Garcia.

text.text:
### The Maternal Lineage (Part I)

The details of how the Camargo family manipulated information regarding the maternal family of Garcia Roiz Paes are documented in the diligence of Pedro Dias Paes, son of Garcia Roiz Paes. According to the testimony of João Gonçalves, Garcia Roiz Paes was prevented from joining the Order of Christ due to family's fame. However, there was no solid basis for these allegations, as João Gonçalves knew the family and had seen the baptism certificate of Maria Garcia

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 20 - 26

text.text: In the same diligence, and in the nobility justification of Pedro Dias Paes, it is stated that Pedro Dias Paes was accepted into the Order of Christ

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 3

text.text:
### The Maternal Lineage (Part II)

The maternal grandparents were the target of defamation for various reasons. The grandfather, García Roiz Velho, favored the Pires family during the Paulista Civil War. This led the Camargo family to claim that he was a New Christian due to his marriage to a member of the Fernandes family, their enemies. Subsequently, they also accused him of not having been ordained as a priest to be a Jew person.

Both accusations were disproven through witness testimonies and documentary evidence, including an emphatic statement from Father Joseph de Mascarenhas

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 20 - 159

text: • "... ele não se ordenou, por vários homicídios e outros delitos, e por esta razão resolveu se casar com Maria Betim."

?
On Genetics
One of the allegations aimed at associating García Roiz Velho with Judaism was his marriage to a member of the Fernandes family, who were supposedly of Jewish origin.

But did García Roiz Velho’s DNA somehow change when he married María Betim?
desc: The question may seem straightforward, but this was precisely the logic behind the Camargos' claim: that through marriage, a person "becomes part of the group". The rationale behind this assertion likely stemmed from genetic to be unknown at the time or from a literal interpretation of texts that were, in fact, metaphorical.

text:
Reflection 2: Where does the fame come from?
Until now, we saw that a Dias Paes was called "Jew dog" and that other negative reputations had origin, firstly, from a marriage and, later, from a distortion of a fact.

Can you imagine what could Camargo's family used to do defamation of the Fernandes?

text.text:
### The Maternal Lineage (Part III)

The fame attributed to María Betim did not originate from her ancestors nor from her own actions. This reputation stemmed from an act by her uncle, André Fernandes, who, while fighting alongside the Pires family during the war, invaded a property belonging to the Camargo family and stole some indigenous people. Enraged, Francisco de Camargo, also known as "Tiger", pursued him, invading a farm while declaring that "André Fernandes was a Jew"

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 47 - 49, 67, 94

text.text: However, the accusation that André Fernandes was a Jew lacked any solid foundation. Evidence of this is found in the account of a member of the Order of Saint Benedict, who, in tears, prevented Francisco from killing André and attested that he was from the same region as the Fernandes family. The monk affirmed that he knew the family well and that they were all Christians. This claim was further corroborated by the Jesuits, who documented a list of priests belonging to the family

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28, 48 - 49

text.text:
### The Maternal Lineage (Part IV)

If there was no solid basis, what was the reasoning used to claim that the Fernandes family were Jews?

When the Jesuits were expelled from São Paulo for aligning with the indigenous people, André Fernandes played a central role in this process. In their attempt to defame and convert the Fernandes family, the Camargos used the following poem, allegedly written by an indigenous person, as their argument

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 48, 67, 94

text:
• Entrô com grande aparato
  • Aun mas de lo que convino
  • Um capitão palatino
  • Nieto de Poncio Pilatos

?
Can a poem be considered a primary source defining the life of the Fernandes family?
desc:
Poems are a literary form often used to exalt individuals or events, as seen in Os Lusíadas (Luiz de Camões). However, beyond the use of poetic license—which allows authors to bend the rules of language—poems are not necessarily tied to historical events. Instead, they can depict imaginary or fictional scenarios, as is the case with Odisséia (Homero).

Given this, the poem in question cannot be classified as a primary source.

text.text:
### With the Word, the Slanderer

In war, the first casualty is truth. Fortunately, historical records help us better understand past events. One detail stands out: various witnesses report that, shortly before his death, the slanderer visited everyone he had defamed to ask for their forgiveness

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 5, 42, 48, 95, 111

### An Attempt to Resurrect Hypothesis 1 (Part I)

Despite various witnesses, documents, and evidence contradicting the hypothesis that the Fernandes were Jewish, José Gonçalves Salvador, in several of his works, frequently referred to them as authentic Jews. However, on some occasions, he expressed doubts, basing his conclusions primarily on a partial document analyzed at this stage

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66

text.text:
### An Attempt to Resurrect Hypothesis 1 (Part II)

Years later, during his master’s program, Marcelo M. A. Bogaciovas, without mentioning that he was working with a partial document, asserted that María Betim might have been Jewish but failed to reference other documents directly associated with the war. However, when he published his book based on his dissertation, Bogaciovas clarified that the document he had used was partial and provided strong evidence that the Fernandes are Christians

source.text: Torre do Tombo. Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66

text.text: ### The Theory After analyzing the available documents, which are contemporaneous to the individuals studied, it was confirmed that, in Brazil, there was a tactic to "convert" Christians into Jews. The studies that attempted to classify the families under investigation as Jewish either presented doubts in their texts or were later revised based on the evidence. Given this scenario, we reject HYPOTHESIS 1 and recognize all the families in this research as Christians
